bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 16, 1946

div1.p: Hench describes his trip to California, where he met with the family of Jesse Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 16, 1946
div1.opener:
Ac
k
July 16, 1946
General and Mrs. J. R. Kean
2804 North Street, North West
Georgetown, Washington 7, D. C.
My dear General and Mrs. Kean:
div1.p:
I just returned last night from California and the meeting of the
American Medical Association, where I read one paper and discussed another.
Mrs. Hench went with me and we had a wonderful time. After the week in
San Francisco, we spent five days in Santa Barbara. I had expected to spend
merely a couple of hours with Houston Lizear, but he and his wife were ex-
tremely kind and courteous to us. They seemed to think that they had to
entertain us most of our time there, so that really we did not have as much
rest as we had hoped. Nevertheless, it was most interesting and profitable
to meet him and his wife. I also met his sister-in-law. When I have more
time than today, I want to tell you of the many interesting things I learned,
particularly of the tragic attitude of Mrs. Lizear. It was a particular
delight for me to have the privilege of telling Houston more about his father
than he had ever known. He and his sister learned nothing, and I mean absolutely
nothing, from his mother. The mention of there father's name was taboo, because
of the terrible misconception which Mrs. Lizear entertained for so many years.
Houston looks very much like his father. He is a shy, quiet, but nevertheless
pleasant man of forty-seven, and it was a real privilege to see him shyly but
eagerly try to find out at this late date what kind of a man his father was.
The privilege of telling him was alone almost worth all the labor that I have
put into this work. There is much more that I will tell you later.

We had a delightful time with the Trubys. We were at their home
once for dinner, and entertained them two or three times down town. They were,
of course, most anxious to hear about you. General Truby has a slight limp
and weakness on the one side, but is really doing very well. He seems happy
and fairly active. It was so nice to meet his very pleasant daughter, and,
of course, Mrs. Truby is charming.

I am so glad that your maid is being cared for by Doctor Crain.
I had not intended to give him that responsibility. That was is own idea.
As you say, he is a very nice man, and I do hope that he can help Elizabeth.
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
